metadata.case_name: Ruler of erstwhile Faridkot State v. Commissioner of Income-Tax

facts.text: Appellant was Ruler of erstwhile Faridkot State.
Assessments made against appellant for years 1946-47 and 1947-48; accounting years Vikram 2002 (13th April 1945 to 12th April 1946) and 2003 (13th April 1946 to 12th April 1947).
Assessee's income from dividends, interest, and capital gains earned in British India not initially brought to tax.
Assessments made under Sec. 34 read with Sec. 23 of Indian Income-tax Act 1922.
Assessee objected claiming immunity from taxation as Ruler of sovereign state under International Law; notices under Sec. 34 time-barred.
Income-tax Officer rejected objections, held Rulers' personal incomes taxable under Act despite International Law immunity in other contexts.
Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed.
Appeal to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal: Judicial Member held no assessment possible as sovereign Ruler; Accountant Member held liable on personal income from British India, Sec. 34 valid.
Tribunal President held in favour of assessee relying on Andhra Pradesh High Court in H.E.H. Mir Osman Ali Khan v. CIT.
Revenue applied under Sec. 66(1); question referred to Punjab and Haryana High Court: Whether assessee not liable to tax on personal income in British India for 1946-47 and 1947-48.
High Court held against assessee relying on Supreme Court reversal in CIT Andhra Pradesh v. H.E.H. Mir Osman Ali Bahadur.
Native States in India subject to sovereignty and protection of British Crown; relations governed by treaties subject to paramountcy.
Notification in Gazette of India 21st August 1891: Native States under suzerainty have no international personality.
Viceroy Lord Reading to Nizam on 27th March 1926: Sovereignty of British Crown supreme; no equality.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the assessee was not liable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, in respect of his personal income (dividends, interest, capital gains) accruing or arising to him in British India in the assessment years 1946-47 and 1947-48.
Whether Rulers of erstwhile Indian Native States enjoyed immunity from taxation under International Law equivalent to foreign sovereigns.

petitioner_arguments.text: Assessee as Ruler of Faridkot State immune from taxation on every source of income by virtue of sovereignty under International Law; cannot be treated as assessee.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: International Law; H.E.H. Mir Osman Ali Khan v. CIT (AP HC); Mighell v. Sultan of Johore; Duff Development Co. v. Govt. of Kelantan; Statham v. Statham & Gaekwad of Baroda; Patiala State Bank v. CIT; Rani Amrit Kunwar v. CIT; Accountant General Baroda v. CIT; A.H. Wadia v. CIT; Maharaja Bikram Kishore v. Province of Assam

petitioner_arguments.text: Facts differ from Nizam case as assessment years prior to Constitution; Act not applicable to Faridkot State.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CIT AP v. H.E.H. Mir Osman Ali Bahadur distinguished

petitioner_arguments.text: Income-tax authorities accepted international status and immunity for public property, issue only private property.

respondent_arguments.text: Rulers of Indian States not sovereigns under International Law; personal incomes taxable; proceedings under Sec. 34 valid.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: CIT AP v. H.E.H. Mir Osman Ali Bahadur (SC)

respondent_arguments.text: Indian Rulers under suzerainty of British Crown; no international personality.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Gazette of India 1891; H.H. Maharajadhiraj Madhav Rao v. Union of India

court_reasoning.text: Rulers of Indian Native States did not possess international personality; subject to paramountcy of British Crown; no immunity from taxation under International Law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hyderabad State and its Ruler did not acquire international personality; cannot rely on International Law for immunity.

court_reasoning.text: Immunity from taxation not uniform under International Law; any exemption must be under relevant taxing Acts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sec. 60 of Act exempted Rulers' income from Central Govt securities, implying liability otherwise.

court_reasoning.text: High Court reference enables consideration of assessee's status as erstwhile ruling prince; not limited to private property.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Status as international personality in issue.

court_reasoning.text: Prior High Court decisions distinguishable or under different Acts; SC in Nizam case directly concludes no immunity for personal properties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: International law on sovereign taxation evolving, not crystallized.

holdings.text: Assessee, Ruler of Faridkot State, not entitled to immunity from taxation under International Law on personal income from British India; liable to tax under Indian Income-tax Act 1922.
Rulers of erstwhile Indian Native States lacked international personality; exemptions only under municipal taxing laws.

precedents_cited.case_name: CIT Andhra Pradesh v. H.E.H. Mir Osman Ali Bahadur
precedents_cited.relevance: Ruler of Hyderabad lacked international personality; no immunity from tax on personal income.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.E.H. Mir Osman Ali Khan v. CIT (AP HC)
precedents_cited.relevance: Held sovereign immune; overruled by SC.
Immunity of Rulers under English common law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Duff Development Co. Ltd. v. Govt. of Kelantan
Statham v. Statham H.H. the Gaekwad of Baroda
Patiala State Bank v. CIT Bombay
Rani Amrit Kunwar v. CIT C.P. U.P.
Accountant General Baroda State v. CIT Bombay
Maharaja Bikram Kishore of Tripura v. Province of Assam
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between State and private property.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.H. Maharajadhiraj Madhav Rao Jivaji Rao Scindia v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Native States had no international personality.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mirza Ali Akbar Kashani v. United Arab Republic

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for assessment, reference, exemption of certain Ruler incomes implying general liability.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Immunity from suits for Rulers with Central Govt consent.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Agricultural Income-tax Act 1944
statutes_cited.relevance: Specifically made Rulers liable, contra to immunity claim.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court judgment answering reference against assessee; held assessee liable to tax on personal income; appeals by special leave dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "Indisputably, a sovereign ruler enjoys immunity from taxation under International Law and it is only in cases where this rule is superseded by express words that this should be denied to him."
key_quotes.speaker: Andhra Pradesh High Court (reversed)
key_quotes.significance: Basis for Tribunal President's view in favour of assessee.

key_quotes.text: "The principles of the International law have no bearing upon the relations between the Government of India... and the Native States under the suzerainty of Her Majesty."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Gazette 1891 negating international personality of Native States.

key_quotes.text: "Hyderabad State did not acquire international personality under the international law and so its Ruler could not rely upon international law for claiming immunity from taxation of his personal properties."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding from Nizam case applied here.
